Bash(.specify/scripts/powershell/create-new-feature.ps1 -Json "AI/Spec-Driven Book Creation: Building and Deploying a Technical Book with Docusaurus and GitHub Pages
Target audience:
Developers, technical writers, and educators interested in AI-assisted, specification-driven content creation (intermediate proficiency in JavaScript/React, Git, and Markdown assumed)
Focus:
A complete, practical guide to creating a high-quality, interactive technical book using Docusaurus, driven entirely by explicit specifications (Spec-Kit Plus) and AI assistance (Claude Code), with full deployment to GitHub Pages
Success criteria:

Readers can follow the book end-to-end to create and deploy their own Docusaurus-based book from scratch
Includes at least 10 fully working, progressively complex examples (from basic site setup to advanced MDX features, plugins, and custom components)
Demonstrates real Spec-Kit Plus workflow with actual specification files and evolution history
Shows concrete Claude Code prompts, iterations, and before/after code comparisons for key sections
Final deployed site is fast, accessible, and serves as a live example of the book''s teachings
Readers understand how to maintain, version, and collaborate on spec-driven documentation projects

Constraints:

Total content: Minimum 20,000 words across at least 10 chapters/sections
Format: Docusaurus-compatible Markdown/MDX files with proper frontmatter, syntax-highlighted code blocks, and embedded interactive elements where appropriate
Tools: Limited to Spec-Kit Plus, Claude Code, Docusaurus (v3 or latest stable), standard free plugins, GitHub, and GitHub Pages
Timeline: Structured for incremental development with clear milestones per chapter
All code examples must run without external paid services

Not building:

General Docusaurus reference manual (link to official docs instead)
In-depth tutorials on unrelated tools (e.g., Next.js, Vercel alternatives)
Commercial theme or premium plugin recommendations
Extensive coverage of advanced React development beyond what''s needed for Docusaurus customization
Discussion of altern" -Number 1 -ShortName "spec-driven-book")
Bash(git add .claude/ my-website/ backend/ frontend/ specs/ history/ .github/)

This commit includes updates to configuration files, Docusaurus documentation site, backend services, and related configurations." -m "ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)" -m "Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>")

Bash(python -c "
import uvicorn
from src.main import app
import threading
import time
import requests
import json

def make_test_request\(\):
    time.sleep\(2\)  # Wait for server to start
    try:
        response = requests.post\(
            ''http://127.0.0.1:8006/api/v1/auth/register'',
            headers={''Content-Type'': ''application/json''},
            json={''email'': ''testuser@example.com'', ''password'': ''test123'', ''name'': ''Test User''}
        \)
        print\(f''Response status: {response.status_code}''\)
        print\(f''Response text: {response.text}''\)
    except Exception as e:
        print\(f''Request error: {e}''\)

# Start request in a separate thread
request_thread = threading.Thread\(target=make_test_request\)
request_thread.start\(\)

# Start server
print\(''Starting server on port 8006...''\)
uvicorn.run\(app, host=''127.0.0.1'', port=8006, log_level=''info''\)
")

Bash(python -c "
import asyncio
import sys
import os
sys.path.insert\(0, os.path.join\(os.getcwd\(\), ''src''\)\)

from src.api.auth_router import register
from src.models.user import UserRegister

async def test_register_function\(\):
    try:
        print\(''Testing register function directly...''\)
        
        user_data = UserRegister\(email=''test@example.com'', password=''test123'', name=''Test User''\)
        result = await register\(user_data\)
        
        print\(f''Register function result: {result}''\)
    except Exception as e:
        print\(f''Error in register function: {e}''\)
        import traceback
        traceback.print_exc\(\)

asyncio.run\(test_register_function\(\)\)
")

Bash(python -c "
import uvicorn
from src.main import app
import threading
import time
import requests
import json

def make_test_request\(\):
    time.sleep\(3\)  # Wait for server to start
    print\(''Making registration request...''\)
    try:
        response = requests.post\(
            ''http://127.0.0.1:8007/api/v1/auth/register'',
            headers={''Content-Type'': ''application/json''},
            json={''email'': ''testuser@example.com'', ''password'': ''test123'', ''name'': ''Test User''}
        \)
        print\(f''Response status: {response.status_code}''\)
        print\(f''Response text: {response.text}''\)
    except Exception as e:
        print\(f''Request error: {e}''\)
        import traceback
        traceback.print_exc\(\)

# Start request in a separate thread
request_thread = threading.Thread\(target=make_test_request\)
request_thread.start\(\)

# Start server with more verbose logging
print\(''Starting server on port 8007 with verbose logging...''\)
uvicorn.run\(app, host=''127.0.0.1'', port=8007, log_level=''debug'', access_log=True\)
")

Bash(python -c "
import asyncio
import sys
import os
sys.path.insert\(0, os.path.join\(os.getcwd\(\), ''src''\)\)

from src.api.auth_router import register
from pydantic import BaseModel

# Create a test user data class that matches UserRegister
class TestUserRegister\(BaseModel\):
    email: str
    password: str
    name: str

async def test_register\(\):
    try:
        print\(''Testing register function...''\)
        user_data = TestUserRegister\(email=''test@example.com'', password=''test123'', name=''Test User''\)
        result = await register\(user_data\)
        print\(f''Register result: {result}''\)
    except Exception as e:
        print\(f''Error in register: {e}''\)
        import traceback
        traceback.print_exc\(\)

asyncio.run\(test_register\(\)\)
")

Bash(python -c "
import asyncio
import sys
import os
sys.path.insert\(0, os.path.join\(os.getcwd\(\), ''src''\)\)

from src.api.auth_router import register
from pydantic import BaseModel

# Create a test user data class that matches UserRegister
class TestUserRegister\(BaseModel\):
    email: str
    password: str
    name: str

async def test_register\(\):
    try:
        print\(''Testing register function after removing local functions...''\)
        user_data = TestUserRegister\(email=''testuser@example.com'', password=''test123'', name=''Test User''\)
        result = await register\(user_data\)
        print\(f''Register result: {result}''\)
        print\(''SUCCESS: Registration worked!''\)
    except Exception as e:
        print\(f''Error in register: {e}''\)
        import traceback
        traceback.print_exc\(\)

asyncio.run\(test_register\(\)\)
")
